Award.AwardTitle: Communication Technologies, Social Tolerance, and Relationship Persistence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Contrary to much current opinion, new communication technologies may facilitate the persistence of social contact and the maintenance of social ties. In so doing, they may increase exposure to a variety of opinions and backgrounds and thereby increase social cohesion and social tolerance. Through the everyday use of new technologies, relationships may be less transitory than in the recent past and people may be increasingly aware of diversity within their personal network of relationships. These trends may aid in the diffusion of information and attitudes between individuals and groups that may otherwise be sparsely or infrequently connected. This project focuses on inter-generational relationships in the context of children departing rural communities for post-secondary education

The goal of this research is to pre-test the design and measures for a longitudinal study into how the use of new communication technologies is related to the stability and durability of people?s relationships, and how awareness of acquaintances? activities might influence social tolerance. Rural communities and the life course transition of a child leaving the community for post-secondary education provides a unique context in which to study these effects. Children who leave for post-secondary education gain experience and diversity, but often do not return to their rural communities. Individuals experience a loss of intergenerational contact, and the rural community does not benefit from the children?s experience. This research uses a mixed methods approach, a survey administered over the internet and by telephone of a sample of first-generation students from rural communities and at least one of their parents or guardians, and a series of interviews with rural households. The survey and interviews will collect information on a variety of processes related to persistence and awareness, including variation in technology use, relational maintenance, social support, and cross-generational contact.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to design and pre-test the procedure and measures for a longitudinal study into how the use of new communication technologies (e.g, social media) might be related to the stability/durability of people's relationships, and how awareness of acquaintances’ activities through these technologies might influence outcomes like social tolerance.

This work tests a new theory in the study of community, that new communication and information technologies facilitate persistent contact and pervasive awareness of social ties. As a result of persistence, relationships may be less transitory than in the recent past. Through the everyday use of new technologies, people may be increasingly aware of diversity, attitudes and other information within their personal network of relationships. The trend toward persistent contact and pervasive awareness may aid in the diffusion of information and attitudes between individuals and groups that may otherwise be sparsely or infrequently connected. This research extends understanding of how the use of new technologies is related to the supportive nature of people's communities, the communication of diverse information, and interaction that could help counter the loss of social capital in contemporary communities.

Rural communities and the life course transition of a child leaving the community for post-secondary education provides a unique context in which to study the role of relational persistence and pervasive awareness. In addition to expanding knowledge and understanding of how new communication technologies are shaping relationships, this project contributes to understanding of how youth leaving rural communities for post-secondary education influences their support networks, families and community.

The specific aims of this project were to pre-test a mixed methods approach that included:

  • a survey administered over the Internet and by mail to a sample off first-generation students from rural communities, and at least one of their parents/guardians;
  • a series of in-depth, in-person interviews with rural households;
  • a new approach to measuring social networks that overcomes possible issues with the validity and reliability of a commonly used measure, the "important matters" name generator.

From the study site, three-thousand and eight-one students were identified as first in their families to attend university and from rural areas. These students were contacted for possible participation. Those who provided voluntary consent to participate were given a confidential Internet/Web-based survey that required approximately twenty-five minutes to complete. Student's parents were contacted by email and postal mail and were also asked to participate. In total, 994 students completed the project survey (32% completion rate). Of those students who completed the survey, 501 had parents who also completed the survey (50% of students who completed).

Qualitative interviews were conducted with twelve families (twenty-six people). Two families were selected from each of five cohorts (incoming, freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior) and two additional families were included because of attitudinal differences between student and parent. Members of the research team traveled to the homes of participating families, and additional interviews were completed on a university campus. Interviews were conducted in a group setting, with at least one parent and child. All interviews were semi-structured, audio recorded, and lasted 60-90 minutes. Each interview began with a discussion of how parents/students felt about the student's move to university, how they stayed in contact (e.g., visits, social media), and what, if anything, they had learned about each other since. Participants were specifically prompted to think about their use of social media and instances when they observed things about each other that might have been unexpected. Audio recordings were subsequently transcribed and de-identified by a professional transcription services.

A short supplemental survey, administered to a sample recruited form Amazon Mechanical Turk, was used to test the validity of a new approach to measuring core networks. A split-ballot was used to compare five approaches to enumerating social networks. This analysis identified problems with commonly used approaches to measuring core networks, and suggest that a new approach, the Restricted Five Generator Design, is a more valid measure of personal support networks.

This work contributes to the disciplines of sociology, computer science, information science, and communication studies by increasing understanding of how the design of social media and related technologies influences outcomes related to relationship maintenance and the spread of information. Graduate students and a post-doctoral scholar were mentored on building social theory aimed at understanding how new technologies influence relationships and attitudes, as well as specialized data skills necessary for contributing future knowledge to this area. The focus on underrepresented populations, in particular rural households of lower socioeconomic status, advanced the aims of overcoming barriers to sampling and recruiting hard-to-reach populations, and increasing scientific engagement among socially disadvantaged and hard-to-reach groups.

This project successfully demonstrated the feasibility of a mixed-methods approach to studying this topic, and successfully evaluated a new approach to measuring social networks.
